description: Account number formats vary by country and provider (length, hyphens, prefix letters). Scammers cite a plausible-looking local account ID.
Displayed caller ID patterns differ by country/region (area codes, short codes, toll-free prefixes). Scammers often spoof a local-looking utility number.
Role title the scammer references to pressure urgency and secrecy; titles and their authority vary by country and company structure (e.g., CFO vs. Finance Director).
Name of the internal IT/helpdesk organization varies by company and region (e.g., "IT Help Desk," "Technology Services," "Service Desk"). Using a specific label makes the impersonation believable.
Scammers reference locally common remote-support tools; the brand/tool varies by country and workplace norms.
MFA/2FA providers differ by region and company, and naming a specific provider increases realism.
Name of the employer’s payroll/self-service system used for direct deposit management; varies by country and company (e.g., region-specific vendors and branding).
The typical way domestic bank routing/branch numbers are referenced and formatted, which differs by country (e.g., ABA routing number in the U.S., sort code in the U.K., BSB in Australia).
External payroll processor name that differs by market and company; scammers often invoke a recognizable local provider to gain credibility.

Name of the company’s code or document repository platform used for project collaboration; varies by country/industry (e.g., GitHub Enterprise, GitLab, Bitbucket, SharePoint) and dictates how access/sharing is requested.
Localized name of the internal shared drive or workspace where confidential project files are stored; naming conventions differ by company/region and influence how users reference locations.
Name of the supposed vendor/partner varies by country and industry, influencing credibility. Different regions have well-known local suppliers or service providers scammers might impersonate.
Invoice numbering schemes differ by country and company (prefixes, year-week, country codes). Including a realistic local format increases plausibility.

Role title varies by country/industry jargon and scam pitch (e.g., ‘remote package handler’ vs. ‘work-from-home compliance assistant’). Using a localized job title makes the offer believable in the target market.
Scammers often name a local or nationally familiar retailer/platform where the ‘training kit’ or ‘work laptop’ must be purchased, which differs by country/region.
Name of a recognizable bank or credit issuer varies by country and even region; using a local institution increases plausibility of the scam.
Payment card networks differ by market; callers may reference a locally common network to sound credible.
Country-specific personal identification number format the scammer may request for credit checks (e.g., national ID, SSN, Aadhaar, NIN). Format and terminology vary by country and culture.
Name of the national or regional financial regulator the scammer might invoke to appear legitimate; varies by country/market.
Scammers often impersonate well-known or locally operating debt collection agencies; the recognizable agency name varies by country and region, influencing plausibility.
Public-market ticker symbols vary by country and exchange conventions; using a realistic local ticker makes the pitch believable (e.g., U.S. uses short uppercase tickers on NYSE/Nasdaq).
Cryptocurrency symbols and the popularity of specific tokens vary by region and exchange availability; scammers often cite locally popular tokens to sound credible.
Health insurers vary widely by country/region; using the correct local insurer name makes the scam believable.
Member ID formats differ by insurer and country; realistic formatting helps localization.

Format/name of a country-specific personal health identifier that scammers might ask for to 'verify eligibility'; varies widely by country (e.g., NHS number in the UK, RAMQ number in Quebec, Medicare number in Australia).
Name of the specific higher-education institution or school, which varies by country and region and signals legitimacy in the scam context.

The localized name of the office handling tuition/fees (e.g., Bursar, Student Accounts, Fees Office), which differs by country and institution.

A locally familiar course name or teacher/professor that varies by country and institution, used to establish credibility (e.g., course naming conventions, honorifics).
A country- or region-specific instant payment instrument or gift card/crypto route commonly exploited in scams; differs by locale in brand and terminology.
Full student name format and common naming conventions vary by country (order, middle initials, patronymics). Needed so the caller can reference the child/student naturally in a school context.
Localized term for the upfront rental payment being demanded (e.g., holding deposit, security deposit, first month’s rent) varies by country and region in naming and legal meaning.

Localized phrasing the scammer uses to deter contacting others or police; wording and references to law enforcement vary by country/region.
substitutions: Jangan tutup teleponnya, tetap bicara sama saya sekarang
Jangan hubungi siapa pun dulu, ini penting
Jangan telepon polisi dulu, ikuti arahan saya
Jangan kasih tahu keluarga atau teman sekarang, tunggu instruksi saya
Tetap di garis ini ya, jangan putuskan teleponnya
Jangan panik dan jangan kontak orang lain, dengarkan saya dulu
english_translation_substitutions: Do not hang up, keep talking to me now
Do not contact anyone yet, this is important
Do not call the police yet, follow my instructions
Do not tell family or friends now, wait for my instructions
Stay on the line, do not end the call
Do not panic and do not contact others, listen to me first
